title: 5. Machine Learning with Random Survival Forests
text: classical models like Cox Proportional Hazards model highly interpretable, rely strict assumptions linear, additive effects. complex biological systems, predictors often interact highly non-linear ways. Random Survival Forests (RSF), implemented via randomForestSRC package, overcome building ensemble decision trees. SuperSurv natively supports RSF. tutorial demonstrates include RSF ensemble perform automated hyperparameter tuning using SuperSurv’s create_surv_grid function.

title: 5. Machine Learning with Random Survival Forests
code: library(SuperSurv) library(survival)  data("metabric", package = "SuperSurv") set.seed(123)  train_idx <- sample(1:nrow(metabric), 0.7 * nrow(metabric)) train <- metabric[train_idx, ] test  <- metabric[-train_idx, ]  X_tr <- train[, grep("^x", names(metabric))] X_te <- test[, grep("^x", names(metabric))] new.times <- seq(50, 200, by = 25)

title: 5. Machine Learning with Random Survival Forests
text: single Random Forest configuration rarely optimal every dataset. Super Learner framework, handle “tuning” adding multiple versions algorithm library, different hyperparameters (like tree depth node size). meta-learner automatically evaluates via cross-validation assigns highest weight best configuration.

what: Approach A: Manual Wrappers (The Hard Way)
title: 5. Machine Learning with Random Survival Forests
text: manually define individual R functions every parameter combination:
code: # A "Fast/Shallow" Forest surv.rfsrc.shallow <- function(..., nodesize = 15) {   surv.rfsrc(..., nodesize = nodesize) }  # A "Deep/Complex" Forest surv.rfsrc.deep <- function(..., nodesize = 3) {   surv.rfsrc(..., nodesize = nodesize) }

what: Approach B: Automated Tuning with create_grid (The SuperSurv Way)
title: 5. Machine Learning with Random Survival Forests
text: Instead writing manual wrapper functions every combination, SuperSurv provides create_grid function. simply supply base learner name list hyperparameter values. function automatically generates wrapper functions environment returns character vector names, ready passed Super Learner library!
code: # Define our hyperparameter search space rf_tuning_params <- list(   nodesize = c(3, 15, 30), # Deep vs. Shallow trees   ntree = c(100, 500)      # Number of trees in the forest )  # Automatically generate 6 different Random Forest wrappers rf_grid <- create_grid(base_learner = "surv.rfsrc",                              grid_params = rf_tuning_params)  # View the dynamically generated function names print(rf_grid) #> [1] "surv.rfsrc_1" "surv.rfsrc_2" "surv.rfsrc_3" "surv.rfsrc_4" "surv.rfsrc_5" #> [6] "surv.rfsrc_6"  # Combine the tuned ML grid with our baseline Cox model my_ml_library <- c("surv.coxph", rf_grid)

title: 5. Machine Learning with Random Survival Forests
text: pass expanded, tuned library SuperSurv. internal cross-validation pit linear Cox model 6 variations non-linear Random Forest.
code: fit_rf_ensemble <- SuperSurv(   time = train$duration,   event = train$event,   X = X_tr,   newX = X_te,   new.times = new.times,   event.SL.library = my_ml_library,   cens.SL.library = c("surv.coxph"), # Keep censoring simple to speed up computation   control = list(saveFitLibrary = TRUE),   verbose = FALSE,   selection = "ensemble",   nFolds = 3 )

title: 5. Machine Learning with Random Survival Forests
text: Let’s see meta-learner distributed weights. step essentially tells us “winning” hyperparameter combination specific dataset. leveraging create_surv_grid(), can easily execute massive hyperparameter search space, mathematically guaranteeing final ensemble minimizes cross-validated risk without manual trial--error!
code: # Extract and round the meta-learner weights round(fit_rf_ensemble$event.coef, 4) #>   surv.coxph_screen.all surv.rfsrc_1_screen.all surv.rfsrc_2_screen.all  #>                  0.3466                  0.1299                  0.3967  #> surv.rfsrc_3_screen.all surv.rfsrc_4_screen.all surv.rfsrc_5_screen.all  #>                  0.0000                  0.1267                  0.0000  #> surv.rfsrc_6_screen.all  #>                  0.0000

title: 2. Model Performance & Benchmarking
text: SuperSurv ensemble trained, must rigorously prove outperforms individual base learners. survival data involves right-censoring, use standard classification metrics like simple accuracy. Instead, evaluate model across three critical dimensions: 1. Calibration: predicted survival probability match actual observed survival rate? 2. Discrimination (AUC & C-index): Can model correctly rank patient survive longer? 3. Overall Accuracy (Brier Score): combined measure calibration discrimination. tutorial demonstrates extract metrics visualize benchmark comparisons using SuperSurv’s built-evaluation suite.

title: 2. Model Performance & Benchmarking
text: begin loading metabric dataset defining evaluation time grid (new.times). Crucial Methodological Note: new.times grid never exceed maximum observed follow-time training cohort. example, training data spans 1 100 days, predicting survival day 150 extrapolation. Non-parametric models (like Survival Trees) mathematically extrapolate, parametric models (like Weibulls) generate highly unreliable tail estimates. Always bind evaluation grid within limits observed data!
code: library(SuperSurv) library(survival)  data("metabric", package = "SuperSurv") set.seed(123) train_idx <- sample(1:nrow(metabric), 0.7 * nrow(metabric)) train <- metabric[train_idx, ] test  <- metabric[-train_idx, ]  X_tr <- train[, grep("^x", names(metabric))] X_te <- test[, grep("^x", names(metabric))]  # Our max follow-up is well beyond 200, so this grid is safe. new.times <- seq(50, 200, by = 25)

title: 2. Model Performance & Benchmarking
text: fit ensemble consisting Cox model, Weibull model, Survival Tree using default Least Squares meta-learner.
code: my_library <- c("surv.coxph", "surv.weibull", "surv.rpart")  fit_supersurv <- SuperSurv(   time = train$duration,   event = train$event,   X = X_tr,   newX = X_te,   new.times = new.times,   event.SL.library = my_library,   cens.SL.library = my_library,   control = list(saveFitLibrary = TRUE),   verbose = FALSE,   nFolds = 3 )

title: 2. Model Performance & Benchmarking
text: eval_summary() function automatically generates predictions test set returns clean, comparative table integrated metrics across entire time grid. Note: Look model lowest IBS (Integrated Brier Score) highest iAUC/Uno’s C-index.
code: # Evaluate performance directly using the fitted model and test data performance_results <- eval_summary(   object = fit_supersurv,   newdata = X_te,   time = test$duration,   event = test$event,   eval_times = new.times ) #>  #> Generating predictions on test data... #> Evaluating SuperSurv Ensemble... #> Evaluating Base Learner 1/3: surv.coxph_screen.all... #> Evaluating Base Learner 2/3: surv.weibull_screen.all... #> Evaluating Base Learner 3/3: surv.rpart_screen.all... #>  #> ======================================================== #>              SuperSurv Evaluation Benchmark              #> ======================================================== #>                    Model    IBS  Uno_C   iAUC #>       SuperSurv_Ensemble 0.2056 0.6317 0.6645 #>    surv.coxph_screen.all 0.2071 0.6291 0.6619 #>  surv.weibull_screen.all 0.2068 0.6289 0.6615 #>    surv.rpart_screen.all 0.2156 0.5931 0.6266 #> ======================================================== #> * IBS & iAUC integrated over: [50.00, 200.00] #> * Uno's C-index evaluated using risk at time: 125.00 #> Note: Lower IBS is better. Higher Uno_C and iAUC are better.

title: 2. Model Performance & Benchmarking
text: single integrated number rarely tells whole story. Different models excel different follow-periods (e.g., Cox model might dominate short-term survival, Random Forest dominates long-term). plot_benchmark() function generates stacked dashboard visualize dynamic performance time.
code: plot_benchmark(   object = fit_supersurv,   newdata = X_te,   time = test$duration,   event = test$event,   eval_times = new.times ) #> Generating predictions for benchmark plots... #> Calculating time-dependent metrics...

title: 2. Model Performance & Benchmarking
text: IPCW Brier Score Plot: Look curve stays lowest. SuperSurv ensemble ideally hug bottom edge. Time-Dependent AUC Plot: Look curve stays highest (closest 1.0). Uno’s C-index Plot: Evaluates global C-index using specific predictions generated time point. Look curve stays highest.

title: 2. Model Performance & Benchmarking
text: deploying model clinic, doctors need know probabilities reliable. model predicts patient 40% chance surviving past Time = 100, exactly 40% similar patients actually survive? use plot_calibration() evaluate specific clinical milestone. function groups patients risk quantiles plots predicted probability actual observed Kaplan-Meier survival rate.  Interpretation: perfectly calibrated model follow 45-degree dashed black line. Points line indicate model -predicting survival (pessimistic), points line indicate -predicting survival (optimistic).
code: # Assess calibration specifically at Time = 150 plot_calibration(   object = fit_supersurv,   newdata = X_te,   time = test$duration,   event = test$event,   eval_time = 150,   bins = 5 # Group patients into 5 risk quintiles )

title: 6. Parametric Survival Models
text: Cox model semi-parametric (leaves baseline hazard unspecified), fully parametric models assume survival times follow specific mathematical distribution, Weibull, Exponential, Log-Normal distribution. Parametric models statistically powerful produce perfectly smooth survival curves. However, highly brittle: assume data follows Weibull distribution, true biological hazard completely different shape, model heavily biased. SuperSurv acts safety net. can include multiple parametric assumptions library. parametric assumption perfectly matches data, SuperSurv give high weight. assumption wrong, cross-validation risk spike, SuperSurv safely assign weight zero.

title: 6. Parametric Survival Models
code: library(SuperSurv) library(survival)  data("metabric", package = "SuperSurv") set.seed(42)  train_idx <- sample(1:nrow(metabric), 0.7 * nrow(metabric)) train <- metabric[train_idx, ] test  <- metabric[-train_idx, ]  X_tr <- train[, grep("^x", names(metabric))] X_te <- test[, grep("^x", names(metabric))] new.times <- seq(50, 200, by = 25)  # Define a library covering different parametric assumptions parametric_library <- c("surv.coxph",       # Semi-parametric baseline                         "surv.weibull",     # Assumes hazard increases/decreases monotonically                         "surv.exponential", # Assumes constant hazard over time                         "surv.lognormal")   # Assumes hazard rises then falls

title: 6. Parametric Survival Models
text: run ensemble exactly . Internally, SuperSurv fit Accelerated Failure Time (AFT) models map continuous survival predictions onto discrete new.times evaluation grid.
code: fit_parametric <- SuperSurv(   time = train$duration,   event = train$event,   X = X_tr,   newX = X_te,   new.times = new.times,   event.SL.library = parametric_library,   cens.SL.library = c("surv.coxph"),   control = list(saveFitLibrary = TRUE),   verbose = FALSE,   selection = "ensemble",   nFolds = 3 )

Final Ensemble Weights:

title: 6. Parametric Survival Models
text: Look closely weights assigned surv.exponential. Exponential distribution assumes risk event (hazard) completely constant time. real-world cancer datasets like metabric, assumption almost always false (risk usually increases time peaks shortly surgery). Exponential assumption fits data poorly, cross-validated risk high, SuperSurv smartly assign weight 0.000.00. including parametric models SuperSurv library, allow data—researcher—dictate mathematical distributions actually appropriate patient cohort!

title: 8. Scaling Up with Parallel Processing
text: Double Super Learner incredibly powerful statistical framework, computationally demanding. define 5 base algorithms use 10-fold cross-validation, SuperSurv fit minimum 50 separate machine learning models just Event ensemble, plus another set Censoring ensemble! default, R executes models sequentially (one ). However, SuperSurv natively supports parallel processing using modern future future.apply ecosystem. allows distribute cross-validation folds across multiple CPU cores, dramatically reducing computation time.

title: 8. Scaling Up with Parallel Processing
text: use parallel processing, need future future.apply packages installed.
code: install.packages(c("future", "future.apply"))

title: 8. Scaling Up with Parallel Processing
text: SuperSurv relies define parallel “plan” running function. gives complete control many resources package allowed consume.
code: library(SuperSurv) library(future) library(survival)  data("metabric", package = "SuperSurv")  # 1. Define the parallel plan # 'multisession' opens background R sessions.  # We tell it to use 4 CPU cores (workers). plan(multisession, workers = 4)

title: 8. Scaling Up with Parallel Processing
text: plan set, simply add parallel = TRUE SuperSurv call. internal cross-validation loop automatically detect workers distribute folds simultaneously.
code: X <- metabric[, grep("^x", names(metabric))] new.times <- seq(50, 200, by = 25)  # 2. Run the model with parallel = TRUE fit_parallel <- SuperSurv(   time = metabric$duration,   event = metabric$event,   X = X,   newX = X,   new.times = new.times,   event.SL.library = c("surv.coxph", "surv.weibull", "surv.rfsrc"),   cens.SL.library = c("surv.coxph"),   parallel = TRUE,     # <--- The magic argument   nFolds = 5 )

title: 8. Scaling Up with Parallel Processing
text: best practice close background workers return standard, sequential processing intensive models finished fitting. frees memory machine.
code: # 3. Return to sequential processing plan(sequential)

title: 8. Scaling Up with Parallel Processing
text: standard parallel processing, random number generation (used heavily cross-validation splits Random Forests) can become disorganized, leading results change slightly every time run code. SuperSurv handles safely hood. parallel = TRUE, package automatically invokes future.seed = TRUE, ensuring parallelized ensemble yields exact mathematically reproducible results sequential ensemble, just much faster!

title: 4. High-Dimensional Data & Variable Screening
text: modern clinical research bioinformatics, common encounter high-dimensional datasets number predictors (genes, biomarkers, clinical features) far exceeds number observed events (p≫np \gg n). Feeding thousands raw variables directly complex machine learning algorithms introduces two massive problems: 1. Computational Bottlenecks: Algorithms like Random Survival Forests become prohibitively slow. 2. Overfitting: Models mathematically memorize background noise instead true biological signals, destroying --sample prediction accuracy. SuperSurv elegantly handles Variable Screening. Screening acts computational filter models fitted. evaluates predictors, drops statistical noise, passes highly associated features base learners.

title: 4. High-Dimensional Data & Variable Screening
text: demonstrate screening works, use standard metabric dataset, artificially inject 100 columns pure random noise. simulates high-dimensional genomic dataset measured features absolutely relationship patient survival.
code: library(SuperSurv) library(survival)  data("metabric", package = "SuperSurv") set.seed(42)  # Create 100 columns of random noise (simulating irrelevant genes/biomarkers) n_patients <- nrow(metabric) noise_data <- matrix(rnorm(n_patients * 20), nrow = n_patients) colnames(noise_data) <- paste0("noise_", 1:20) # Combine the real data with the noise high_dim_data <- cbind(metabric, noise_data)  # Standard Train/Test Split train_idx <- sample(1:nrow(high_dim_data), 0.7 * nrow(high_dim_data)) train <- high_dim_data[train_idx, ] test  <- high_dim_data[-train_idx, ]  X_tr <- train[, grep("^x|^noise", names(high_dim_data))] X_te <- test[, grep("^x|^noise", names(high_dim_data))] new.times <- seq(50, 200, by = 25)

title: 4. High-Dimensional Data & Variable Screening
text: Just library prediction algorithms, SuperSurv utilizes library screening algorithms. can pair prediction model screening function create streamlined pipeline. SuperSurv includes comprehensive suite built-screeners: * screen.marg: Marginal screening (keeps variables strong univariate associations). * screen.glmnet: Penalized Lasso screening (shrinks irrelevant feature coefficients exact zero). * screen.elasticnet: Elastic Net screening (combines Lasso Ridge penalties; highly recommended highly correlated biological features like gene expression data). * screen.rfsrc: Tree-based screening (keeps features high Random Forest variable importance). * screen.var: Unsupervised screening (drops features near-zero variance). * screen.: baseline passthrough (keeps variables without screening). Let’s build library tests different combinations prediction screening:
code: # We pass a list of vectors. The first element is the prediction model,  # and the second element is the screening algorithm.  my_screen_library <- list(   c("surv.coxph", "screen.all"),         # Baseline: Cox model with ALL variables   c("surv.coxph", "screen.marg"),        # Screen by marginal association, then fit Cox   c("surv.weibull", "screen.elasticnet"),# Screen via Elastic Net, then fit Weibull   c("surv.rpart", "screen.var")          # Drop zero-variance noise, then fit a Tree )  # For the censoring library, we use an unscreened approach  cens_library <- c("surv.coxph")

title: 4. High-Dimensional Data & Variable Screening
text: pass paired library SuperSurv, meta-learner handles cross-validation absolute statistical rigor. Crucial Methodological Detail: screening step performed inside cross-validation folds. screen entire dataset splitting folds, cause “data leakage,” leading overly optimistic benchmark metrics. SuperSurv protects automatically.
code: fit_highdim <- SuperSurv(   time = train$duration,   event = train$event,   X = X_tr,   newX = X_te,   new.times = new.times,   event.SL.library = my_screen_library, # Pass our screened library   cens.SL.library = cens_library,   control = list(saveFitLibrary = TRUE),   verbose = T,   nFolds = 3 )

title: 4. High-Dimensional Data & Variable Screening
text: Despite injecting 100 columns pure noise, ensemble still performs exceptionally well screening algorithms successfully filtered irrelevant variables base learners overfit . can evaluate exactly previous tutorials using eval_summary() plot_benchmark(). leveraging SuperSurv’s screening capabilities, can scale survival analysis massive genomic clinical datasets without sacrificing computational speed predictive accuracy.
code: # Check the integrated performance screened_performance <- eval_summary(   object = fit_highdim,   newdata = X_te,   time = test$duration,   event = test$event,   eval_times = new.times ) #>  #> Generating predictions on test data... #> Evaluating SuperSurv Ensemble... #> Evaluating Base Learner 1/4: surv.coxph_screen.all... #> Evaluating Base Learner 2/4: surv.coxph_screen.marg... #> Evaluating Base Learner 3/4: surv.weibull_screen.elasticnet... #> Evaluating Base Learner 4/4: surv.rpart_screen.var... #>  #> ======================================================== #>              SuperSurv Evaluation Benchmark              #> ======================================================== #>                           Model    IBS  Uno_C   iAUC #>              SuperSurv_Ensemble 0.2014 0.6373 0.6779 #>           surv.coxph_screen.all 0.2009 0.6350 0.6794 #>          surv.coxph_screen.marg 0.2004 0.6270 0.6775 #>  surv.weibull_screen.elasticnet 0.2005 0.6324 0.6798 #>           surv.rpart_screen.var 0.2106 0.6104 0.6349 #> ======================================================== #> * IBS & iAUC integrated over: [50.00, 200.00] #> * Uno's C-index evaluated using risk at time: 125.00 #> Note: Lower IBS is better. Higher Uno_C and iAUC are better.  # Plot the benchmark # plot_benchmark(fit_highdim, newdata = X_te, time = test$duration, event = test$event, eval_times = new.times)

title: 4. High-Dimensional Data & Variable Screening
text: Super Learner finishes cross-validation fitting, likely want know variables actually survived screening process. clinical biological research, selected features often represent important biomarkers predictive genes. SuperSurv stores screening information directly inside fitted model object, specifically separated event.whichScreen cens.whichScreen. can extract logical matrix indicates columns passed specific base learner. extracting features, can seamlessly transition pure predictive modeling downstream biological inference pathway analysis.

# The event.whichScreen object is a logical matrix. # Rows correspond to the predictors, and columns correspond to the algorithms in our event library.  # 1. Get the logical vector for the 2nd model (Row 2) is_selected <- fit_highdim$event.whichScreen[2, ]   # 2. Map it to our original column names selected_features <- colnames(X_tr)[is_selected]  cat("Total features evaluated:", ncol(X_tr), "
") #> Total features evaluated: 29 cat("Features retained by Elastic Net:", length(selected_features), "

") #> Features retained by Elastic Net: 10  cat("Selected Features:
") #> Selected Features: print(selected_features) #>  [1] "x0"       "x1"       "x2"       "x3"       "x4"       "x5"       #>  [7] "x6"       "x7"       "x8"       "noise_10"

title: 7. Interpreting the Black Box with SHAP
text: Machine learning models, particularly tree-based algorithms deep ensembles, notoriously criticized “black boxes.” often achieve superior predictive performance compared classical linear models, clinicians bioinformaticians need know model making specific prediction. SuperSurv solves using SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations). Shapley values possess mathematical property linearity, SuperSurv can calculate SHAP values every active base learner seamlessly combine using meta-learner’s weights. tutorial covers Global feature importance, Local (patient-level) explanations, Feature dependence, Time-Dependent survival heatmaps.

title: 7. Interpreting the Black Box with SHAP
text: Let’s train diverse Super Learner metabric dataset.
code: library(SuperSurv) library(survival)  # Load data data("metabric", package = "SuperSurv") set.seed(42)  train_idx <- sample(1:nrow(metabric), 0.7 * nrow(metabric)) train <- metabric[train_idx, ] test  <- metabric[-train_idx, ]  X_tr <- train[, grep("^x", names(metabric))] X_te <- test[, grep("^x", names(metabric))] new.times <- seq(50, 200, by = 25)  # Fit a diverse library my_library <- c("surv.coxph", "surv.weibull", "surv.rpart")  fit_sl <- SuperSurv(   time = train$duration,   event = train$event,   X = X_tr,   newX = X_te,   new.times = new.times,   event.SL.library = my_library,   cens.SL.library = c("surv.coxph"),   control = list(saveFitLibrary = TRUE),   verbose = FALSE,   selection = "ensemble",   nFolds = 3 )

title: 7. Interpreting the Black Box with SHAP
text: calculate SHAP values, need X_explain dataset (patients want explain) X_background dataset (reference population used calculate baseline average risk).
code: # For speed in this tutorial, we explain the first 50 test patients # using 100 training patients as the background reference. X_explain_subset <- X_te[1:50, ] X_background_subset <- X_tr[1:100, ]  # Calculate weighted Ensemble SHAP values shap_vals <- explain_shap(   model = fit_sl,    X_explain = X_explain_subset,    X_background = X_background_subset,    nsim = 20 )

title: 7. Interpreting the Black Box with SHAP
text: features drive ensemble’s mortality risk predictions across entire cohort?
code: plot_global_importance(shap_vals, top_n = 5)

title: 7. Interpreting the Black Box with SHAP
text: beeswarm plot gold standard SHAP. shows magnitude feature’s impact direction effect based feature’s actual value. Interpretation: red dot (high feature value) right side vertical zero-line indicates higher values biomarker increase mortality risk.
code: plot_beeswarm(shap_vals, data = X_explain_subset, top_n = 5)

title: 7. Interpreting the Black Box with SHAP
text: precision medicine, often need explain specific patient high low risk score. Waterfall plot breaks exact algorithmic logic individual.
code: # Explain Patient #1 from our test subset plot_patient_waterfall(shap_vals, patient_index = 1, top_n = 5)

title: 7. Interpreting the Black Box with SHAP
text: specific biomarker linear non-linear relationship mortality risk? dependence plot visualizes algorithm uses specific feature across entire distribution.
code: # Let's look at the relationship for feature 'x0' plot_dependence(shap_vals, data = X_explain_subset, feature_name = "x0")

title: 7. Interpreting the Black Box with SHAP
text: Traditional SHAP looks overall “risk score,” survival analysis fundamentally time. SuperSurv natively bridges survex package evaluate predictions across survival curve S(t)S(t). can visualize patient trajectories time using survival heatmap. Interpretation: Patients top experience rapid drops survival probability (high risk), patients bottom maintain high survival probabilities throughout follow-period. utilizing SHAP tools, SuperSurv ensures advanced machine learning ensembles remain completely transparent, interpretable, ready clinical deployment.
code: # Plot the survival trajectories for the first 50 test patients plot_survival_heatmap(fit_sl, newdata = X_explain_subset, times = new.times)

title: 3. Ensemble vs. Best Model Selection
text: theoretical framework Super Learning, two distinct ways utilize cross-validated risks base algorithms: Ensemble Super Learner: Calculates weighted average (convex combination) base learners. “soft selection” smooths variance, integrates different feature spaces, generally yields lowest finite-sample prediction error. “Best” Model Selector: Identifies single algorithm lowest cross-validated risk assigns weight 1.0 (others 0.0). “hard selection” “winner-take-” approach. Ensemble asymptotically optimal, selecting single best model incredibly useful interpretability strictly tied one specific algorithm family. Instead manually cherry-picking best model—introduces researcher bias invalidates post-selection inference—SuperSurv automates selection using rigorous, internal cross-validation. can easily toggle two paradigms using selection argument.

title: 3. Ensemble vs. Best Model Selection
text: load metabric dataset define evaluation time grid exactly previous tutorials.
code: library(SuperSurv) library(survival)  data("metabric", package = "SuperSurv") set.seed(42)  # Standard Train/Test Split train_idx <- sample(1:nrow(metabric), 0.7 * nrow(metabric)) train <- metabric[train_idx, ] test  <- metabric[-train_idx, ]  X_tr <- train[, grep("^x", names(metabric))] X_te <- test[, grep("^x", names(metabric))] new.times <- seq(50, 200, by = 25)  # Define a diverse library of base learners my_library <- c("surv.coxph", "surv.weibull", "surv.rpart")

title: 3. Ensemble vs. Best Model Selection
text: fit two separate SuperSurv models. first use default Ensemble approach (selection = "ensemble"), second use winner-take-approach (selection = "best").
code: # 1. The Ensemble Super Learner (Weighted Average) fit_ensemble <- SuperSurv(   time = train$duration,   event = train$event,   X = X_tr,   newX = X_te,   new.times = new.times,   event.SL.library = my_library,   cens.SL.library = my_library,   control = list(saveFitLibrary = TRUE),   verbose = FALSE,   selection = "ensemble",     # <-- Calculates fractional weights   nFolds = 3 )  # 2. The 'Best' Super Learner (Winner-Take-All) fit_best <- SuperSurv(   time = train$duration,   event = train$event,   X = X_tr,   newX = X_te,   new.times = new.times,   event.SL.library = my_library,   cens.SL.library = my_library,   control = list(saveFitLibrary = TRUE),   verbose = FALSE,   selection = "best",         # <-- Selects the single best model   nFolds = 3 )

title: 3. Ensemble vs. Best Model Selection
text: difference two methodologies immediately obvious inspect meta-learner coefficients (event.coef). Interpretation: Notice Ensemble Super Learner distributes weight across multiple models minimize overall loss function. “Best” Super Learner simply looks cross-validated risk, identifies champion, gives 100% weight.
code:
cat("
--- ENSEMBLE WEIGHTS (selection = 'ensemble') ---
") #>  #> --- ENSEMBLE WEIGHTS (selection = 'ensemble') --- print(round(fit_ensemble$event.coef, 4)) #>   surv.coxph_screen.all surv.weibull_screen.all   surv.rpart_screen.all  #>                  0.5152                  0.1680                  0.3167  cat("
--- BEST MODEL WEIGHTS (selection = 'best') ---
") #>  #> --- BEST MODEL WEIGHTS (selection = 'best') --- print(round(fit_best$event.coef, 4)) #> [1] 1 0 0

title: 3. Ensemble vs. Best Model Selection
text: common question clinical research : “complexity Ensemble actually perform better simply picking best single model?” can answer instantly using eval_summary(). comparing resulting Brier scores C-indices, can empirically justify whether “soft selection” ensemble mathematically necessary specific dataset, “hard selection” single model sufficient.
code:
# Evaluate the Ensemble cat("Performance of the ENSEMBLE Super Learner:

title: 1. SuperSurv with Ensemble
text: core feature SuperSurv package ability combine multiple base survival learners highly predictive meta-ensemble. tutorial walks preparing data, defining library models, fitting Super Learner, generating predictions new patients.

title: 1. SuperSurv with Ensemble
text: use built-metabric dataset, extracting covariates performing standard 80/20 train-test split.
code: library(SuperSurv) library(survival)  # Load built-in METABRIC data data("metabric", package = "SuperSurv")  # Quick 80/20 Train-Test split set.seed(42) n_total <- nrow(metabric) train_idx <- sample(1:n_total, 0.8 * n_total)  train <- metabric[train_idx, ] test  <- metabric[-train_idx, ]  # Extract just the X covariates (assuming they are named x0, x1, etc.) x_cols <- grep("^x", names(metabric), value = TRUE) X_tr <- train[, x_cols] X_te <- test[, x_cols]  # Define the prediction time grid (e.g., survival at 50, 100, 150, 200 months) new.times <- c(50, 100, 150, 200)

title: 1. SuperSurv with Ensemble
text: define library base survival models. quick demonstration, use lightning-fast parametric tree-based models.
code: my_library <- c("surv.coxph", "surv.weibull", "surv.rpart")

title: 1. SuperSurv with Ensemble
text: run main SuperSurv engine, important understand key parameters. Super Learner algorithm relies cross-validation assign weights base models, must model event censoring mechanism avoid biased evaluations. complete guide arguments need pass:

title: 1. SuperSurv with Ensemble
text: time: numeric vector observed follow-times training cohort. event: numeric vector indicating status observed time (typically 1 = event occurred, 0 = right-censored). X: data.frame matrix containing predictor variables (covariates) training set. include time event columns ! newX: (Optional) data.frame covariates validation test set. provided, SuperSurv immediately generate predictions patients training phase, saving step. new.times: numeric vector defining exact time points want survival probabilities predicted (e.g., seq(50, 200, = 25)).

title: 1. SuperSurv with Ensemble
text: event.SL.library: character vector base algorithms used predict actual survival outcome (e.g., "surv.coxph", "surv.rpart"). cens.SL.library: library used estimate censoring mechanism time. SuperSurv uses predictions calculate Inverse Probability Censoring Weights (IPCW). can use exact library event models, simpler one.

title: 1. SuperSurv with Ensemble
text: "least_squares" (Default): Optimizes weights minimizing IPCW Brier score. Excellent overall prediction accuracy. "nloglik": Optimizes weights minimizing negative log-likelihood. Excellent improving hazard discrimination. nFolds: number cross-validation folds used train meta-learner. V = 5 V = 10 standard. cross-validation prevents ensemble overfitting base learners. control = list(saveFitLibrary = TRUE): tells engine save fitted base learners final object. required want use predict() method new patients later. verbose: Set TRUE print progress messages console. Highly recommended large datasets complex libraries can track cross-validation progress. Let’s fit two models verbose = FALSE see meta-learner choice affects final ensemble weights.
code: # Fit 1: Least Squares Meta-learner fit_ls <- SuperSurv(   time = train$duration,   event = train$event,   X = X_tr,   newX = X_te,                 # Predict on the test set immediately   new.times = new.times,       # Our evaluation time grid   event.SL.library = my_library,   cens.SL.library = my_library,   metalearner = "least_squares",    control = list(saveFitLibrary = TRUE),    verbose = T,             # Turn to TRUE in practice to see progress!   selection = "ensemble",   nFolds = 5                   # 5-fold CV for the meta-learner )  # Fit 2: Negative Log-Likelihood Meta-learner fit_nll <- SuperSurv(   time = train$duration,   event = train$event,   X = X_tr,   newX = X_te,   new.times = new.times,   event.SL.library = my_library,   cens.SL.library = my_library,   metalearner = "nloglik",       # Swap to nloglik   control = list(saveFitLibrary = TRUE),    verbose = FALSE,   selection = "ensemble",   nFolds = 5 )

what: 4. Inspect the Ensemble Weights and Risks
title: 1. SuperSurv with Ensemble
text: defining feature Super Learner just pick single “best” model; finds optimal weighted combination models based cross-validated performance. Let’s inspect weights (event.coef) cross-validated risks (event.cvRisks) meta-learners.
code:
cat("
--- LEAST SQUARES METALEARNER ---
") #>  #> --- LEAST SQUARES METALEARNER --- print(round(fit_ls$event.coef, 4)) #>   surv.coxph_screen.all surv.weibull_screen.all   surv.rpart_screen.all  #>                  0.2344                  0.5906                  0.1750 cat("CV Risks (Lower is Better):
") #> CV Risks (Lower is Better): print(round(fit_ls$event.cvRisks, 4)) #>   surv.coxph_screen.all surv.weibull_screen.all   surv.rpart_screen.all  #>                  0.4856                  0.4854                  0.4958  cat("
--- NLOGLIK METALEARNER ---
") #>  #> --- NLOGLIK METALEARNER --- print(round(fit_nll$event.coef, 4)) #>   surv.coxph_screen.all surv.weibull_screen.all   surv.rpart_screen.all  #>                   0.000                   0.684                   0.316 cat("CV Risks (Lower is Better):
") #> CV Risks (Lower is Better): print(round(fit_nll$event.cvRisks, 4)) #>   surv.coxph_screen.all surv.weibull_screen.all   surv.rpart_screen.all  #>                  0.6554                  0.6245                  0.6521

previous_headings: 4. Inspect the Ensemble Weights and Risks
title: 1. SuperSurv with Ensemble
text: event.coef: final weights assigned base learner. weight 0 means meta-learner completely dropped model contribute overall predictive accuracy. high weight means model heavily influences final ensemble prediction. Notice least_squares nloglik algorithms might distribute weights differently based optimization goals! event.cvRisks: cross-validated error individual base learner. meta-learner uses errors calculate optimal weights. Lower risk always indicates better performance.

title: 1. SuperSurv with Ensemble
text: passed newX training phase, SuperSurv already calculated predictions test set. However, real-world clinical setting, often train model predict brand new patients months later. set control = list(saveFitLibrary = TRUE) training, can use standard R predict() method.
code: # Select 3 brand new patients from our test set new_patients <- X_te[1:6, ]  # Generate predictions using the Least Squares ensemble ensemble_preds <- predict(   object = fit_ls,    newdata = new_patients,    new.times = new.times )  cat("\n--- PREDICTED SURVIVAL PROBABILITIES ---\n") #>  #> --- PREDICTED SURVIVAL PROBABILITIES --- final_matrix <- ensemble_preds$event.SL.predict colnames(final_matrix) <- paste0("Time_", new.times) rownames(final_matrix) <- paste0("Patient_", 1:6)  print(round(final_matrix, 4)) #>           Time_50 Time_100 Time_150 Time_200 #> Patient_1  0.7910   0.5800   0.4053   0.2717 #> Patient_2  0.9249   0.8344   0.7404   0.6473 #> Patient_3  0.9054   0.8000   0.6948   0.5944 #> Patient_4  0.8369   0.6624   0.5048   0.3720 #> Patient_5  0.8552   0.6974   0.5504   0.4219 #> Patient_6  0.7321   0.4865   0.3026   0.1775

title: 1. SuperSurv with Ensemble
text: predict() function returns list, important element event.SL.predict. * Rows (NN): Represent individual patients. * Columns (TT): Represent specific time points defined new.times. * Values: estimated probability patient survive past specific time point. time increases (moving left right across row), survival probability naturally decreases.

title: 1. SuperSurv with Ensemble
text: raw probability matrices (N×TN \times T) perfect downstream coding performance benchmarking, difficult interpret clinically. Doctors researchers need see actual survival trajectories. SuperSurv includes built-plot_predict() function effortlessly translate matrix publication-ready survival curves individual patients.
code: # Plot the predicted survival curves for our 3 new patients (Rows 1, 2, and 3) plot_predict(   preds = ensemble_preds,   eval_times = new.times,   patient_idx = 1:6 )

title: 1. SuperSurv with Ensemble
text: now know prepare data, define model library, choose meta-learner, generate patient-specific survival curves. However, deploying model clinical practice, must rigorously prove ensemble actually outperforms individual base learners. Head Tutorial 2: Model Performance & Benchmarking learn generate time-dependent Brier Score, AUC, Uno’s C-index plots!

text: time Observed follow-time. event Observed event indicator. X Training covariate data.frame. newX Test covariate data.frame prediction (defaults X). new.times Times obtain predicted survivals. event.SL.library Character vector prediction algorithms event. cens.SL.library Character vector prediction algorithms censoring. id Cluster identification variable. verbose Logical. TRUE, prints progress messages. control List control parameters Super Learner. cvControl List control parameters cross-validation. obsWeights Observation weights. metalearner Character string specifying optimizer (e.g., "least_squares"). selection Character. Specifies meta-learner combines base models. Use "ensemble" (default) calculate weighted average (convex combination) base learners. Use "best" act Discrete Super Learner, assigns weight 1.0 single model lowest cross-validated risk. nFolds Number cross-validation folds (default: 10). parallel Logical. TRUE, uses future.apply parallel execution.
